title: How to think Steve Jobs would handle streaming and Apple Music today - Quora

response.answer_text: Of all the massive (and largely unnoticed) disasters of Tim Cook’s tenure as chief executive of Apple, the one that would have most appalled Steve Jobs, I think, is the Apple Music app. Music (in the form of the iPod and iTunes) is what made Apple relevant again, and Jobs, as everyone knows, was almost as passionate about great music as he was about making great products. So it would come as an absolute horror to Jobs that Apple’s music app, since the launch of Apple Music, has been a repulsive, preposterously unintuitive mess. He would take one look at it and want to kill everyone involved in its creation. It’s the absolute antithesis of everything that he believed in, as far as software design is concerned. I suspect he would do something along the lines of what I would do (and what Apple’s designers no doubt considered doing when they were developing the app). Split the app into two “sides.” On one side, My Music, and on the other, Apple Music. You switch between the two sides by tapping a button in the top-left corner of the screen. When you switch sides, everything on the screen, except the Now Playing bar, changes. The tabs on the bottom of the screen pertain exclusively to the side of the app that you’re on (so when you’re in My Music, the tabs are “Songs,” “Artists,” “Albums,” etc., and when you’re in Apple Music, the tabs all have to do with discovering new music). This would make the app so fucking simple and elegant. Also, he would make everything far more aesthetically pleasing. Album art would be much more prominent. And the fonts wouldn’t look like the fonts on a website from 1996.

I think Apple Music launched poorly. The introduction at WWDC was awkward and the app was such a mess that they completely re-designed it within a year. In terms of Steve Jobs’ attitude to streaming music in general, that’s hard to say. He’s on the record as being against it, but he’s on the record as being against a lot of things Apple ended up doing while he was CEO. In fact, one of my favourite quotes of his is “If the market tells us we’re making the wrong decisions, we listen to the market. We’re just people trying to run this company.”
